III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12206 Staff qualifications; volunteer,
Section contractors on central registry
Description • (2) A staff member must be of responsible character and
suitable and able to meet the needs of children and families
served by the agency.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation It is alleged that Staff 1 is not providing the youth with entitled
funding and placed youth in a shelter and told youth if he does not
like it he can go back to his country.
Investigation This investigation was conducted jointly with DHHS Worker
The investigation was initiated on 01/17/2025 with a phone call to
the DHHS Worker during which discussion occurred regarding
proceeding with the investigation.
The Holy Cross Children’s Services (HCCS) Program
Manager was interviewed face to face at the HCCS facility on
01/28/2025.
The Program Manager is the administrator for the HCCS
Independent Living Program where all youth interviewed reside.
The Program Manager reported that Youth B and C were placed
in the program on 12/23/2024. The Program Manager reported
Youth B and C are refugees from Sudan and were placed by
Bethany Christian Services Refugee Program. The Program
Manager reported Youth B and Youth C received $250.88 plus
$124.44 in money last week. The Program Manager reported that
this amount comes to the youth twice monthly. The Program
Manager reported Youth B and Youth C received this money
during the middle cycle of the payment period. The Program
Manager reported Youth C was informed of the payment cycling
period several times but feels he is being short changed of money
owned to him. The Program Manger reported that the language
barrier with Youth B and Youth C is significant as neither speak
English. The Program Manager reported that debit cards are
being obtained for each youth because bank accounts cannot be
obtained for the youth because of their refugee status. The
Program Manager reported that Bethany receives $1600 dollars
from the Federal government for each youth and $900 of that will
be loaded onto the debit cards. The Program Manager reported
2

that until the money situation is completed Youth A and Youth B
have money and are receiving appropriate care from the agency.
Youth A was interviewed face to face on 01/28/2025 at the
HCCS Independent Living Program. Youth A recently graduated
from the program. Youth A reported he received $385.84 dollars
every two weeks. Youth A reported that $134.96 of the $385.84
went to rent. The rest could be used for food and clothes. Youth A
reported that staff would take him to buy clothes on occasion.
Youth A reported that he always had food even if he was running
low. Youth A reported that Youth B and Youth C and the other
residents always have food and eat regularly. Youth A reported
that staff are respectful towards him. Staff 1 is not his worker.
Youth B was interviewed face to face on 01/28/2025 at the
HCCS Independent Living Program. The language barrier is
significant as Youth B does not speak English. DHHS Worker
used a language translation application on her phone in order to
communicate with Youth B. Youth B reported that the ILP house is
like a prison and when asked to elaborate, he reported he is there
24 hours a day and it is “boring”. Youth B reported he does get
food. Youth B reported he has received money but not all of it.
Youth B reported he understands that he will receive twice
monthly amounts of $250 dollars and that he has received $250
dollars so far. Youth B reported he has not received last month’s
money but understands the program is working out getting the rest
of the money. Youth B reported that he feels safe at the program.
He did not report concerns about Staff 1
Youth C was interviewed face to face on 01/28/2025 at the
HCCS Independent Living Program. The language barrier is
significant as Youth C does not speak English. DHHS Worker
used a language translation application on her phone in order for
us to communicate with Youth C. Youth C reported that he got his
money but not all of it and he wants his own place. It was
explained to Youth C that he will be receiving additional money as
it is being processed. Youth C reported that he wants, but
understands, his own independent living home may not be
available right now. Youth C reported he can go to the food pantry
and then said, “we get meat, but I am not a good cook”. Youth C
reported he can’t share a bathroom as he had been subjected to
rape attempts while traveling. Youth C did not report any concerns
about Staff 1.
Youth D was interviewed face to face on 01/28/2025 at the
HCCS Independent Living Program. Youth D reported that he
3

receives YIT funds amounting to $749.00 every two weeks. Youth
D reported that he pays $200 for rent. Youth D reported staff take
him to the store, or he walks to store. Youth D reported that a food
truck comes to the program every Wednesday. Youth D reported
everyone has enough food. Youth D reported there are four
bathrooms in the house, and he has privacy when using the
bathroom. Youth D reported the staff at the program are “straight”
and treat him with respect. Staff 1 is not the worker for Youth D.
Youth E was interviewed face to face on 01/28/2025 at the
HCCS Independent Living Program. Youth E reported he
receives $385 dollars twice a month and $134.96 goes for rent.
Youth E reported that he also receives food stamps. Youth E
reported there is enough food at the program and he feels safe.
Staff 1 is not the worker for Youth E.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face on 02/06/2025. Staff 1 is
the Bethany Christian Services Refugee program caseworker for
Youth C. Staff 1 reported Youth C was never left at a shelter. Staff
1 reported Youth C was in a Bethany foster home for a very short
period before being placed at the HCCS Independent Living
Program. Staff 1 denied that she ever told Youth C that if does not
like it he can go back to where he came from. Staff 1 reported that
she did say to Youth C that he runs the risk of being deported if he
does not comply with the program. Staff 1 reported MDHHS
provides $800 dollars per month for Youth C in twice monthly
payments of $400 dollars. Staff 1 reported that HCCS takes out
$220 per month for rent. Staff 1 reported refugees receive $1650
as part of an overseas funding and youth can receive this money
when they turn 18 years of age. Staff 1 reported Youth C
requested part of the overseas funding and she presented him
with a check of $900 dollars on 01/22/2025. Staff 1 reported
HCCS set up a banking account with Wildfire Banking for Youth C.
Staff 1 reported that on 01/17/2025 Youth C received the first
month stipend check. Staff 1 reported that prior to this she had
$90 dollars and took Youth C shopping on 12/23/2024. Staff 1
reported on 12/30/2024 she had a $100 dollar Walmart gift card
and also used the Bethany credit card to purchase food for Youth
C. Staff 1 reported on 01/07/2025 she used the company credit
card to purchase food for Youth C. Staff 1 reported these
purchases were made until Youth C’s stipend checks began to
arrive. Staff 1 reported when Youth C’s stipend money began and
the overseas check was presented to him he purchased a
television and a new phone.
4

Staff 1 had documents that she presented to us for review.
Video Review
01/23/2025 video of Youth B and C records was reviewed, please
note there is no audio. Video showed them obtaining food from
the food storage cupboard. A 01/14/2025 video records Youth B
making food and eating. A 01/09/2025 video records Youth C
eating.
DOCUMENT REVIEW:
A check dated 01/09/2025, for $1650 dollars payable to the order
of Youth C was reviewed.
A check dated 01/21/2025 for $900 dollars was made out to Youth
C.
A HCCS stipend statement dated 01/17/2025 documents that
Youth C was to receive $125.44 dollars for the time period from
12/23/24 through 12/29/2024.
A HCCS stipend statement dated 01/21/2025 documents that
Youth C was to receive $250.88 dollars for the time period from
12/30/2024 through 01/12/2025.
Food purchases. A receipt of food purchases by Staff 1 for Youth
C was reviewed.
Case File Review: The file documents that Youth C was an
unaccompanied refugee from Sudan and arrived in the United
Staes on 12/18/2024, entered the Bethany refugee program and
was placed in a Bethany foster home on the same date. Youth C
was then placed in the HCCS independent living program on
12/23/2024. The file did not add any other information relevant to
the investigation.
Analysis Youth C was placed in a Bethany foster home and then in HCCS
ILP. Youth C was not placed of left in a shelter. Staff 1 denied that
she told Youth C if he doesn’t like his placement he can go back
to where he came from and she took Youth C shopping on
12/23/2024, 12/20/2024 and 01/07/2025 with agency funds to
purchase food and necessities. Youth C began receiving ILP
program stipend money on 01/17/2025. Youth C also received a
check for $900 dollars on 01/22/2025. Documents confirm that the
aforementioned payments to Youth C occurred.
5

During the interview with Youth C he stated he is receiving his
money but not all of it. Youth C seemed to have difficulty
understanding that he entered the program during the mid-cycle
payment period and he would receive all money due to him.
Youth A, D, and E all reported that they receive their monthly
stipends. Youth B reported that he has received part of his money
but reported the program is working to obtain the rest of his
funding.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
